dt: {bc}free from guilt or sin especially through lack of knowledge of evil {bc}{sx|blameless||}

dt.t: … searching for a hidden motive in even the most {wi}innocent{/wi} conversation.

dt: {bc}lacking or reflecting a lack of sophistication, guile, or self-consciousness {bc}{sx|artless||}, {sx|ingenuous||}

dt.t: … perfectly {wi}innocent{/wi} of the confusion he had created …

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin {it}innocent-, innocens{/it}, from {it}in-{/it} + {it}nocent-, nocens{/it} wicked, from present participle of {it}nocēre{/it} to harm {ma}{mat|noxious|}{/ma}
shortdef: free from legal guilt or fault; also : lawful
free from guilt or sin especially through lack of knowledge of evil : blameless
harmless in effect or intention; also : candid

dt: {bc}a person who is innocent: such as
{bc}a person free from sin {bc}a young child

dt.t: … during a great land boom in which immense fortunes were made and {wi}innocents{/wi} like himself fleeced.

dt: {bc}a blameless person {bc}a person who does not deserve to be harmed

dt.t: The war caused the death of thousands of {wi}innocents{/wi}.

shortdef: a person who is innocent: such as
a person free from sin : a young child
a naïve, inexperienced, or unsophisticated person
name of 13 popes: especially II died 1143 (pope 1130—43); III 1160(or 1161)—1216 (pope 1198—1216); IV died 1254 (pope 1243—54); XI 1611—1689 (pope 1676—89)
